Award.AwardTitle: L3 Graduate Student Workshop in Symplectic/Contact Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a week long workshop, titled "L3 Graduate Student Workshop in Symplectic/Contact Geometry," held at New Orleans, Louisiana, on January 19-23, 2016. Symplectic Geometry is a field that connects several research areas such as mathematical physics, geometric topology, algebraic geometry, mirror symmetry and string theory. The goal of this workshop is to introduce participants to contemporary research and discuss future directions. Graduate students will give the majority of the talks. The workshop may serve as a pilot for a future annual event for students of symplectic topology and geometry.

The focus of the workshop is exploring connections between Weinstein manifolds and contact geometry, with Lefschetz fibrations and algebraic geometry. Weinstein manifolds are central objects of study in symplectic geometry and mirror symmetry. They are often given the structure of Lefschetz fibrations, which describes their geometry in terms of Lagrangian submanifolds of a Weinstein manifold of one dimension less. Alternatively, one can describe the geometry in terms of Legendrian submanifolds in a contact manifold. As contact geometry is generally more flexible, this allows us to make a number of additional geometric cancellations and makes the combinatorics of the computations easier. The workshop will begin with a discussion of the essential objects and tools in the theory, and end with current research and new directions. The workshop webpage is at http://math.stanford.edu/~ksiegel/workshop/main.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award was meant to fund a conference for graduate students in symplectic geometry, studying Lefschetz fibrations and related topics. These funds were spent as intended, and the conference was very successful with its aims.

 

The conference covered a number of topics related to Lefschetz fibrations and Weinstein manifolds, loosely organized around approaching the paper "Legendrian fronts for affine varieties" by the PI and R. Casals (another organizer). Though, many of the talks discussed tangentially related topics and other connected applications and tools.

 

Besides success with the mathematical content, the conference was also successful in having graduate students gain experience giving talks. Furthermore, it was also effective in fostering comminity building among students, as the conference was almost entirely organized and run by students. Twenty seven percent of the participants were women.

 

As a result of the conference, a set of notes were published on the conference website.

 

One of the largest goals of the conference was to turn it into a larger event that would occur every year, with a rotating set of graduate student organizers. Wonderfully, this has been successful. A follow up conference, Kylerec 2017, was held in the Spring of 2017, and funded by DMS 1722470. Organization for a 2018 conference is currently underway.
